Award.AwardTitle: Research Initiation Grant: how collaborative PBL and community inquiry affect self-efficacy of minority groups in engineering

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
This engineering education research initiation grant will create a partnership between engineering faculty and engineering education researchers to explore development of self-efficacy in electrical engineering students from a broad range of under-represented groups and first generation college students. The researchers plan to develop a conceptual framework that will let them explore the effect of collaborative learning on self-efficacy then design internal policies for course design and development.

The broader significance and importance of this project arises from the potential of the project to broadly inform practice that can lead to improved retention of under-represented and first generation students. This project overlaps with NSF's strategic goals of transforming the frontiers through preparation of an engineering workforce with new capabilities and expertise. Additionally NSF's goal of innovating for society is enabled by building the capacity of the nation's citizenry for addressing societal challenges through engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Addressing the Learning Needs of Minority Students in Engineering through Participatory Design Approach

Project-based Learning (PBL) has been embraced by the engineering education community in recent years. A natural question is to find out if PBL is the way to go to educate the next generation of engineers? With the support of NSF RIGEE program, an interdisciplinary study was conducted at California State University Los Angeles to investigate the relationship between the pedagogical components in Collaborative Project-based Learning (CPBL) model and the self-efficacy, motivation, and other learning indicators of students in minority groups in Engineering, which shed some light on the above intriguing question.  In addition, engineering educators worked closely with learning scientists to explore an innovative instructional design method based on Participatory Design strategy and situated learning framework to address the needs of target learners in engineering. The research consisted of two stages that spanned across three years. The first stage study was conducted in 2013, which focused on enhancing the understanding of the learning characteristics of minority students, and the effectiveness of CPBL pedagogy. The second stage research involved a course redesign experiment using Participatory Design approach as well as validating the resulted instructional system through iterative implementation in 2014 and 2015.

Analysis of both quantitative and qualitative data showed that CPBL positively contributed to the development of skills critical to student success in engineering areas, including cognitive, social, motivational, and specific engineering design skills. In particular, Hispanic students reported larger growth of self-efficacy through CPBL compared to their non-minority peers. Our research findings further revealed a qualitative difference in students’ learning outcomes as a result of adopting the redesigned CPBL model. Student participation has increased significantly and the performance of term projects has improved.  Many student teams went beyond the basic requirements to apply more advanced and realistic design criteria, indicating a
deeper and more active learning approach was employed.  Clearly, with Participatory Design approach and situated learning framework, the redesigned course helped to sustain the student motivation and promote deep learning. 


The broader significance and importance of this project can be summarized as follows. First, the research established a valid conceptual framework and developed useful instruments to measure the students’ responses to various pedagogical components in CPBL, which can be adopted by other engineering educators and researchers. The research findings contributed to a better understanding of how to improve the self-efficacy of minority students in engineering, so better educational policy can be made to increase their academic success and consequently diversify the engineering workforce. The pilot course redesign process using Participatory Design approach produces useful guidelines of effective instructional system design, which can be broadly exportable to other institutions and engage a wide spectrum of engineering students.
